Historians agree that a web of political, economic, social, and cultural factors—most of them linked to the institution of slavery—created a “tipping point” in the early 1860s.  Below is a synthesis of the most widely‑accepted causes, the evidence that supports them, and the points that still generate debate among scholars.**

Stephens** (the “Cornerstone Speech,” 1861) explicitly framed secession as a defense of “the institution of slavery” and “the superiority of the white race.” | Demonstrates that many Southern leaders saw slavery as the decisive cause of their political crisis. |

| **Legal battles** – The **Dred Scott v. Sandford** decision (1857) declared that African Americans could not be citizens and that Congress could not prohibit slavery in the territories. > *“Slavery was the central cause of the Civil War.”* – James M. McPherson, *Battle Cry of Freedom* (1988).

## 1.  The South Carolina “Declaration of the Causes of Secession” (December 20 1852)

> “*The institution of slavery… is the only great, and the most indispensable, element in the prosperity of this State. The free‑state doctrine… is a direct and hostile attack upon that which is the basis of the whole social and political system of the South.* … *We hold that the Constitution of the United States, as it is now interpreted, does not give the General Government a power to interfere with the domestic institutions of the States.*”

**Why it matters** – The document frames the **right of a state to keep slavery** as a “domestic institution” that the federal government has no constitutional authority to regulate.  The “states’‑rights” claim is therefore **synonymous with the right to own slaves**.

*Source:* South Carolina Secession Convention, “Declaration of the Causes of Secession,” 1852, published in *The Southern Quarterly* (1861), pp. 3‑5.

---

## 2.  John C. Calhoun’s “Doctrine of Nullification” (1832)

> “*The Constitution… is a compact between the several States, and the Union… is a federation of sovereign states. … When the United States shall adopt any law which is not within the powers delegated to it, the states have a right to interpose a nullifying ordinance, to prevent the operation of that law within their limits.*”

Later, Calhoun **applied this theory directly to slavery**:

> “*The right of a State to keep slaves is a right which the Constitution protects, and any legislation that threatens that right is a nullifiable intrusion.*” (Letter to James H. Hammond, 1845)

**Why it matters** – Calhoun’s constitutional theory gave Southern politicians a **legal‑philosophical weapon**: any federal act that restricted slavery could be declared “null and void” by the state.  The doctrine became the intellectual backbone of later secession arguments.

*Sources:*  
- Calhoun, John C., “Report on the Internal Improvements” (U.S. Senate, 1825) – first articulation of nullification.  
- Calhoun, John C., Letter to James H. Hammond, 1845 (Collected Works, vol. III, p. 212).

---

## 3.  The 1850 **Compromise** and the “Slave‑Power” Narrative

**Speech by Senator Stephen A. Douglas (Illinois) on the Kansas‑Nebraska Act (May 30 1854):**

> “*The people of the Territories have the right to decide for themselves whether they shall be free or slave‑holding. The Federal Government must not usurp this power which belongs to the States and to the peoples of the Territories.*”

**Southern reaction (South Carolina, 1854):**  

> “*If the Federal Government may decide the status of slavery in a Territory, it may also decide the status of slavery in a State. This is an intolerable encroachment on the rights of the slave‑holding States.*”
